projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

But the presence of the reader was felt even while the play was still on th (the) stage. It was for him that composed that extraodinary (extraordinary) composition the . He sees through a thousand green shads (shades) what lies immidately (immediately) before him-- the unhappy heart of man. The reflections serve to chequer the immediate spectacle. From books he has won the tolerant sense that we are not singl (single) figures but innumerably rep ated (repeated). In pursuit of melancholy he travels over the whole world, though he has never left his college room. We are at a remove from the thing treated. We are enjoying the spectacle of melancholy, not sharing is anguish.

It is here then that we develop facuoties (faculties) that the play left dormant. to stop; to pause; to refelct (reflect); to Now the reader is completely in being. He can pause; he can ponder; he can compare; he can draw back from the page and see behind it a man sitting alone in the centre of the labyrinth of words in a college room thinkinh (thinking) of suicide. He can gratify many different moods. He can read directly what is on the page, or, drawing aside, can read what is not written. There is a long drawn continuity in the book that the paly (play) has not. It gives a different pace to the mind. We are in a world where nothing is concluded.
